div.p: In this paper we introduce a new RKDG method for problems of wave propagation that achieves full high-order convergence in time and space. The novelty of the method resides in the way in which it marches in time. It uses an mth-order, m-stage, low storage SSP-RK scheme which is an extension to a class of non-autonomous linear systems of a recently designed method for autonomous linear systems. This extension allows for a high-order accurate treatment of the inhomogeneous, time-dependent terms that enter the semi-discrete problem on account of the physical boundary conditions. Thus, if polynomials of degree k are used in the space discretization, the RKDG method is of overall order m = k + 1, for any k > 0. Moreover, we also show that the attainment of high-order space-time accuracy allows for an efficient implementation of post-processing techniques that can double the convergence order. We explore this issue in a one-dimensional setting and show that the superconvergence of fluxes previously observed in full space-time DG formulations is also attained in our new RKDG scheme. This allows for the construction of higher-order solutions via local interpolating polynomials. Indeed, if polynomials of degree k are used in the space discretization together with a time-marching method of order 2 k + 1, a post-processed approximation of order 2 k + 1 is obtained. Numerical results in one and two space dimensions are presented that confirm the predicted convergence properties.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Largely motivated by the increased demand for general, flexible and versatile simulators for a variety of engineering and industrial applications, and enabled by advances in computer technology, the simulation of electromagnetic wave propagation has become a central problem in presentday computational science. Still, and in spite of significant advances over the last 20 years, a variety of military and civilian applications remain well beyond the reach of the simulation capabilities of state-of-the-art numerical methods for Computational Electromagnetics (CEM) [23]. These limitations are, in fact, due to the stringent demands that the nature of waves imposes on their numerical simulation. This demand, in turn, arises from the need to use discretizations that not only resolve material variations and geometrical features of a device or structure, but that also guarantee the resolution of all radiation wavelengths present in any given experiment.

For relatively simple, "electrically small" geometries, classical methods (e.g., MoM [17,20], FDTD [19,26], etc.) may be suitable for simulation; as geometries of interest get more complex or as radiation frequencies increase, however, simulations quickly exceed the domain of applicability of standard approaches. Indeed, classical implementations suffer from an inordinate increase in computational cost to attain a prescribed accuracy as the complexity of the problem increases due to two main reasons. On the one hand, the calculation of the electromagnetic interaction between degrees of freedom will typically dominate the computational cost, and it can easily render it prohibitive for simulations of interest if not efficiently formulated. And, on the other hand, even if these interactions are effectively addressed (e.g., via a variational formulation [21] or with an accelerated integral equation solver [24]), standard implementations typically yield only low (first, second) orders of convergence, leading to severe limitations in the size of problems that they can accurately simulate. Although both of these issues have long been recognized, significant algorithmic advances have only recently emerged. Indeed, for instance, over the past decade a number of schemes have been proposed to accelerate the evaluation of electromagnetic interactions in integral equation formulations that have made these competitive (in computational cost) with finite-element (FE) procedures for volumetric scattering applications (and that, actually, outperform FE methods in surface scattering configurations) (see e.g., [4,5,24]). In addition, significant effort has also gone into the design of integral-equation solvers that exhibit high-order convergence (see e.g., [5,6,11]).

The issue of convergence rates in CEM simulations has also been recently addressed within FE methods. Indeed, for instance, a computational framework based on high-order spatial Nédélec elements has been presented in [7]. With regards to interactions between degrees of freedom, on the other hand, finite-element techniques provide an inherently efficient approach due to the local character that these interactions exhibit in discretized variational formulations (which, of course, translate into sparse matrix equations). In fact, the potential enhancement of this local character of interactions provided, in part, a motivation to apply recently developed discontinuous Galerkin methodologies [8,9] to computational electro-magnetism [18]. Indeed, in [18] a slight variant of the Runge-Kutta discontinuous Galerkin (RKDG) method developed for nonlinear hyperbolic systems in [8] was implemented for the numerical solution of Maxwell's equations with high-order spatial accuracy. For the time integration, however, only a (low-storage) fourth-order Runge-Kutta scheme was used which limits the overall convergence order of the method (unless, of course, an appropriately small time step is adopted).

In this paper, we introduce a new RKDG method that achieves full high-order convergence in time and space while keeping the time-step proportional to the spatial mesh-size. To this end, we derive an extension to non-autonomous linear systems of the mth-order, m-stage strong stability preserving Runge-Kutta (SSP-RK) scheme with low storage described in [14]. With this time-integration scheme, and if polynomials of degree k are used in the space discretization, our RKDG method can be made to converge with overall order m = k + 1, for any k > 0. In particular, as we detail in Sec. 2, the scheme allows for a high-order accurate treatment of the inhomogeneous (time-dependent) terms that enter the semi-discrete problem on account of the physical boundary conditions.

Our choice to extend the method of [14] is motivated by a number of desirable attributes it displays, most notably its SSP property, its ease of implementation and its computational efficiency. We note, however, that the approach we take to carry out the extension to the inhomogeneous case (Sec. 2.2) does not depend on these properties, and it can therefore be easily applied to other time-marching schemes (including multistep procedures or RK methods for non-linear problems; see, e.g. [12,25]). Also, with regards to the specific SSP-RK scheme we adopt here, we note that an alternative extension was recently proposed in [13] to deal with inhomogeneous systems of ordinary differential equations. This latter scheme relies on a reformulation of the time-dependent, non-autonomous system in the form of an autonomous problem augmented with additional auxiliary unknowns which need to be evolved in time. As it turns out, our own procedure can be seen to be equivalent to the extension in [13] in some cases (see the discussion at the end of Sec. 2.2). However, in contrast with that implementation, the approach we present here does not require the introduction of additional unknowns and, as a consequence, it leads to significantly smaller computational effort and memory requirements.

Finally, the availability of a fully high-order scheme as the one we derive here, presents advantages that go beyond the intended reduction in computational cost to achieve a desired accuracy in CEM simulations. Indeed, as we show in Sec. 3, the attainment of high-order space-time convergence allows for an efficient implementation of post-processing techniques that can double the convergence order in one space dimension. These techniques are based on the observation that numerical fluxes "super-converge" (i.e., converge with higher order than is to be expected) and are thus related to the developments in [2]. Indeed, this latter study demonstrates the superconvergence of fluxes within a full (space-time) DG formulation of (two-dimensional) semilinear first-order hyperbolic scalar equations. Here, in turn, we show that similar results hold for an approach based on the method of lines to treat linear hyperbolic systems, provided the time-discretization is compatible with the enhanced convergence orders that is, provided we use our newly derived SSP-RK scheme with an order that is double that of the spatial discretization. Indeed, if polynomials of degree k are used in the space discretization together with a time-marching method of order 2 k + 1, a post-processed approximation of order 2 k + 1 is obtained.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. First, in Sec. 2 we describe our numerical approach. In particular, in Sec. 2.1 we introduce a modal formulation for the space dependence of the fields and we describe our choice of numerical fluxes ("upwind") entering a (discontinuous) variational formulation. In Sec. 2.2, on the other hand, we present a derivation of the m-th order RK scheme that we propose for the time integration. Section 3 then, contains some numerical results in one and two space dimensions that confirm the expected convergence orders. There, we also demonstrate the possible use of these high-order schemes to enable a post-processing of solutions to attain global super-convergence. Finally, we end with some concluding remarks in Sec. 4.

div.head: NUMERICAL RESULTS: HIGH-ORDER ACCURACY AND SUPER-CONVERGENCE
div.p: In this section we present a series of numerical results that confirm the expected high-order space-time convergence of the method described in Sec. 2. We begin in Sec. 3.1 with scattering experiments in one-dimensional configurations, where we consider the propagation of a wave in homogeneous and inhomogeneous media. In these cases, we further demonstrate the super-convergence of numerical fluxes at inter-element boundaries and we use this to derive, via the now classical ENO interpolation, a procedure that exhibits order 2k + 1 using polynomials of degree k. Finally, we present two-dimensional results that demonstrate the high-order convergence of the algorithm in unstructured grids.

div.head: CONCLUDING REMARKS
div.p: In this paper, we have proposed a new RKDG method for computational electromagnetics that, for any given k 0, attains k + 1 order of convergence in both space and time while maintaining the time-step proportional to the mesh-size. A novelty of the method resides in the time-integration procedure for which it resorts to a suitable extension to non-autonomous systems of the mth-order, m-stage, low storage SSP-RK method introduced in [14] for autonomous ODEs. A variety of numerical examples confirmed the expected high-order rates of convergence. In addition, we have shown that the attainment of these rates in space and time allows for the effective utilization of superconvergent quantities to construct improved approximations. Specifically, onedimensional examples demonstrate the possibility of deriving a method of overall order 2k + 1 using only polynomials of degree k. Finally, our basic considerations clearly extend to higher dimensions and to other linear, not necessarily hyperbolic, model equations. In particular, building on the present developments, forthcoming work on the Maxwell system will extend our high-order space/time implementations and superconvergent post-processing to full two-dimensional scattering configurations that include approximations to exact non-reflecting boundary conditions.
